conclusion: Analyze the flow of liquid from points A, B, and C to predict whether they'll end up in container D or E.
Image 1 shows points A, B, and C at the top, angled baffle rods in the middle, and containers D and E at the bottom.
Liquid from A (pink) flows straight down and encounters no baffles initially.
Liquid from A hits the brown baffle and gets deflected slightly to the left.
Pink liquid continues downward, forming drops that follow a path toward the left side.
The trajectory of pink liquid leads it toward container E.
Liquid from B (white) flows straight down and hits the green baffle.
Liquid from B is deflected slightly to the right.
White liquid appears to interact with the blue baffle.
White liquid continues on a path that directs it toward container D.
Liquid from C (green) flows down at an angle and follows the green baffle's direction.
Green liquid appears to continue flowing right.
The path of green liquid directs it toward container D.
Liquid from point A will flow into container E, while liquid from points B and C will flow into container D.
